The following individuals contributed to this cross-chapter box:

- Authors: A.K. Magnan, M. Garschagen, J.-P. Gattuso, J.E. Hay, N. Hilmi, E. Holland, F. Isla, G. Kofinas, I.J. Losada, J. Petzold, B. Ratter, T. Schuur, T. Tabe, and R. van de Wal
- Review Editor: Joy Pereira
- Chapter Scientist: Jan Petzold

This cross-chapter box should be cited as: Magnan et al. (2019): Cross-Chapter Box 9: Integrative Cross-Chapter Box on Low-Lying Islands and Coasts. In: IPCC Special Report on the Ocean and Cryosphere in a Changing Climate (Pörtner et al., eds.).

Cross-Chapter Box 9: Integrative Cross-Chapter Box on Low-Lying Islands and Coasts

Executive Summary:

Low-lying islands and coasts (LLIC), including Small Island Developing States (SIDS), are already experiencing the impacts of ocean and cryosphere changes, with cascading and compounding risks. Disproportionately higher risks are expected in the 21st century. The findings of the IPCC Special Report on Global Warming of 1.5°C suggest that vulnerable human communities, especially those in coral reef environments and polar regions, may exceed adaptation limits well before the end of this century, even in a low greenhouse gas emission pathway.

Depending on the effectiveness of 21st century mitigation and adaptation pathways under all emission scenarios, most of the low-lying regions around the world may face adaptation limits beyond 2100 due to the long-term commitment of sea level rise. LLIC host around 11% of the global population, generate about 14% of the global Gross Domestic Product, and comprise many world cultural heritage sites.

LLIC already experience climate-related ocean and cryosphere changes, and they share commonalities in their exposure and vulnerability to climate change, such as low elevation, human disturbances to terrestrial and marine ecosystems. However, they also have context-specificities, such as variable ecosystem climate sensitivities and risk perceptions by populations.

Options to adapt to rising seas include hard engineering, ecosystem-based measures, securing current settings, and relocating people, built assets, and activities. Effective combinations of measures vary across geographies, reflecting the scale of observed and projected impacts, ecosystems' and societies' adaptive capacity, and the existence of transformational governance.

Introduction:

LLIC are already experiencing the impacts of climate-related changes to the ocean and cryosphere, including extreme events and slow onset changes, due to their low elevation, narrow ecological zonation, climate-sensitive ecosystems, and natural resources, as well as increasing anthropogenic pressures. High levels of impacts to coastal morphology, ecosystems, and dependent human communities are detectable today, and disproportionately higher risks are expected in the 21st century, even under a low emission pathway compatible with a 1.5°C global warming.

The magnitude of projected impacts will depend on future greenhouse gas emissions and associated climate changes, as well as other drivers such as population movement into risk-prone areas and societal efforts to adapt. LLIC include a wide diversity of systems, ranging from tropical to polar regions, and support urban and rural societies from across the development spectrum, including SIDS and Least Developed Countries.
